post_text: Each fall, our high school students participate in colloquium, a special time where they get to explore various topics through research, guest speakers, and hands on demonstrations and projects. This year's theme was "WorldFest," where students partnered by advisory group to immerse themselves in the culture, customs, and worldview of specific nations. Students listened to guest speakers discuss experiences in Ghana, South Africa, Costa Rica, China, and England, and they learned many new things about these and other countries. To wrap up their three day colloquium, students presented their countries of study to the entire upper school. Students prepared native dishes, performed dances, wore colorful costumes, and sang songs to help present their country's culture to others.

post_text: First graders really enjoyed a special presentation by Ms. Kelly Manual, a nurse practitioner with Northern Family Medicine. Ms. Manual allowed the students to see how germs were spread by using a special lotion which, under a black light, illustrates how germs could be transmitted by shaking hands. Students also felt their pulse before and after jumping to see how their heart rates increased, and they got to use pieces of yarn to get an idea of how long their small intestines are. These activities are part of their study of human body systems.

post_text: Upper School students celebrated Honor Day by reflecting on the MCA code and culture of honor. At the beginning of the day, advisories participated in activities to help deepen students’ understanding of being honorable. After that, the ceremonial part of the day began with the induction of six students into the National Honor Society, and following that, students attended a special honor code signing in the gym. Mrs. Merry Craig Boaz, Executive Director of the United Fund of Surry, spoke to the students about giving to the community of their time, their gifts, and their knowledge. Following a charge from the Headmaster, each student signed the MCA Honor Code, which states: As an individual with endowed worth and value, I will honor others with the same respect that I am due. I will uphold the high ideals of this institution with integrity by being respectful, honest, compassionate, responsible and courageous.

post_text: First graders visited Mabry Mill to learn about early pioneer life in our general region. Students got first hand experience watching wool spun into yarn, grinding corn to make meal, and observing blacksmith work, and they even got to try bartering, a practice that was once popular in the area, to trade goods among their various groups in order to obtain all the supplies they needed to make cornbread. After visiting the mill, students enjoyed a picnic lunch at nearby Rocky Knob. It's a Great Day At MCA! #GDAMCA
